Nevertheless, many of the same dynamics that have characterized consumers\u0026rsquo; feelings in the past year\u0026mdash;including a cautiousness toward spending and a simultaneous willingness to splurge\u0026mdash;remain evident. We also observe some growing gaps among demographic groups: for example, younger consumers report significantly higher optimism than older consumers, while male and female respondents in our survey report feeling differently about the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe following five charts showcase findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;survey, which was conducted in the United States from late July 2024 through the first week of August.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story Aug241]]\n[[pullquote aug241]]\n[[Story Aug242]]\n[[pullquote aug242]]\n[[Story Aug243]]\n[[pullquote aug243]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the third quarter, US consumers report higher optimism, buoyed by greater faith in their household finances, which translates into a greater willingness to spend. As keen market watchers already know, emerging economic indicators could dampen this newfound optimism. While we expect the observed differences between demographic groups to remain through the end of the year, the next few months may be turbulent. Market uncertainty, the upcoming US general election, and ongoing geopolitical conflicts may test US consumers\u0026rsquo; faith in the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWatch this space for regular updates on the state of the US consumer. To contact us for more information or to read additional insights, check out our \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise page\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/becca-coggins\"\u003eBecca Coggins\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Chicago office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/christina-adams\"\u003eChristina Adams\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a partner in the Dallas office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/kari-alldredge\"\u003eKari Alldredge\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a partner in the Minneapolis office, and \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/warren-teichner\"\u003eWarren Teichner\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors wish to thank Andrea Leon, Andrew Pitakos, Christina Anderson, Christina Sexauer, Eitan Urkowitz, and Tom Skiles for their contributions to this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Alexandra Mondalek, an editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader May2024]]\n\u003ch6\u003eBy \u003ca href=\"/our-people/christina-adams\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eChristina Adams\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/kari-alldredge\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eKari Alldredge\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;Lily Highman, and\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/our-people/sajal-kohli\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eSajal Kohli\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUS consumer confidence dips as inflationary concerns intensify. Here\u0026rsquo;s the latest research from our ConsumerWise team.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the second quarter\u003c/strong\u003e of 2024, US consumer optimism fell, mirroring levels seen at the end of 2023. Economic pessimism grew slightly, fueled by concerns over inflation, the depletion of personal savings, and perceived weakness in the labor market. These concerns left consumers somewhat conflicted: on one hand, they continued to splurge on food and apparel, but they pared back spending in other areas. This contradictory behavior is most evident with Gen Zers, who traded down and splurged at higher rates than other consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe following five charts highlight the findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story May241]]\n[[PullQuote May241]]\n[[Story May242]]\n[[PullQuote May242]]\n[[Story May243]]\n[[PullQuote May243]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe United States may be seeing evidence of consumers on the cusp of a shift as optimism about the economy declines, trade-down behavior continues, and consumers pull back their spending on nonessential goods. Watch this space for regular updates on the state of the US consumer. Here\u0026rsquo;s the latest research from our ConsumerWise team.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn February, \u003c/strong\u003econcerns about inflation decreased slightly from the previous quarter, which helped consumer optimism about the US economy reach its highest level in almost two years. Although US consumers felt less pressure to save for an eventual rainy day, 20 percent were still pessimistic about the economy\u0026mdash;but this represented the lowest reported pessimism rate since June of 2022 (although consumers were still more pessimistic than they were at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic). The following five charts highlight the findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story Feb1]]\n[[PullQuote Feb1]]\n[[Story Feb2]]\n[[PullQuote Feb2]]\n[[Story Feb3]]\n[[PullQuote Feb3]]\n[[Story Feb4]]\n[[PullQuote Feb4]]\n[[Story Feb5]]\n[[PullQuote Feb5]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs inflation figures continue to fluctuate, will consumers continue to gain confidence in the economy and, therefore, continue to express an interest in splurging? Or will higher-for-longer interest rates slow spending? Watch this space for regular updates on the state of the US consumer. Check out our \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise page\u003c/a\u003e, and contact us for data from previous updates or additional insights.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/christina-adams\"\u003eChristina Adams\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Dallas office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/kari-alldredge\"\u003eKari Alldredge\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a partner in the Minneapolis office, \u003cstrong\u003eLily Highman\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in the New York office, and \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/sajal-kohli\"\u003eSajal Kohli\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a senior partner in the Chicago office.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors wish to thank Isabelle Engelsted, Alex Lequerica, Andrew Pitakos, Tom Skiles, and Eitan Urkowitz for their contributions to this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Alexandra Mondalek, an editor in the New York office. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader Dec2023]]\n\u003ch6\u003eBy \u003ca href=\"/our-people/christina-adams\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eChristina Adams\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/kari-alldredge\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eKari Alldredge\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/sajal-kohli\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"color: #2155ff;\"\u003eSajal Kohli\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and Eitan Urkowitz\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUS shoppers are keeping a watchful eye on their spending as uncertainty about the world around them persists. Here\u0026rsquo;s the latest research from our ConsumerWise team.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDespite inflation slowing\u003c/strong\u003e considerably from its mid-2022 peak, consumers still expressed caution in November about overspending, given lingering uncertainty about the economy and geopolitical tensions. Consumers said they are planning to reduce their overall spend, being more selective in the products they purchase and places they splurge. The following five charts highlight the findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in the United States. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story 1]]\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n[[Story 2]]\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n[[Story 3]]\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n[[Story 4]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWill US consumer sentiment trend up or down as we head into the new year? Despite the increase, economic volatility and concerns over the economy may affect US consumer optimism through the end of 2024.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnsurprisingly, high-income consumers were more optimistic about the economy in the third quarter than middle- and low-income consumers. But age, not income, seems to be the main determinant of third-quarter results. Gen Zers and millennials across income groups report higher rates of optimism compared with Gen Xers and baby boomers. This could be related to the long-term unemployment rate, since a higher percentage of Gen Xers are \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2023/07/07/the-mtv-generations-unemployment-problem-00105150#:~:text=Workers%20born%20between%201964%20and,Glassdoor's%20Chief%20Economist%20Aaron%20Terrazas\"\u003elong-term unemployed\u003c/a\u003e, or unemployed for more than 27 weeks, than those in younger generations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother divergence among demographic groups stood out: male respondents note higher levels of optimism (47 percent) compared with female respondents (37 percent). Levels of optimism increased relative to the second quarter for both groups, and the gap between male optimism and female optimism has held steady for the past year. Male respondents report feeling optimistic about an improved job market in the third quarter, while female respondents indicate feeling concerned over making ends meet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile inflation has consistently dropped from its 2022 peak, 53 percent of respondents in our survey still say that rising prices and inflation are among their concerns. This may be due to an \u0026ldquo;inflation overhang,\u0026rdquo; or the idea that it takes consumers months, if not years, to adjust to new, higher prices even as inflation stabilizes. Not all consumers are slow to catch on: 37 percent of respondents say that stabilizing inflation has made them feel more optimistic about the economy, up from 31 percent in the previous quarter. Several retailers have announced plans to lower prices on everyday items, which may be contributing to higher optimism.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19050270"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"1785D90FB23B40BFA536736CD3435146","mediaID":{"value":"aug242"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"8A7481B2C7E2420B9AC9DD63D1DB74D8","name":"Flourish 2","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn the most recent survey, consumers indicated they planned to increase their spending on most essential, semi-discretionary, and discretionary items over the next three months. In a few categories, including fresh produce and home improvement and gardening supplies, consumers say they plan to decrease their spending compared with the second quarter. This makes sense, given that consumers are probably expecting to spend less on gardening supplies as summer winds down and fall begins.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19050258"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"59F5C2FD2E5C437CBD79171450F3DC9F","name":"Flourish 3","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eConsumers, especially Gen Z and millennials, continue to be price sensitive. Seventy-six percent of consumers report trading down\u0026mdash;that is, changing the type or quantity of purchases for better value and pricing\u0026mdash;in the third quarter, consistent with earlier in the year; however, that figure rises ten percentage points, to 86 percent, among Gen Zers and millennials. Among these younger consumers, nearly 50 percent report changing retailers for a lower price or discount, up from 44 percent last quarter. Gen Xers report trading down at a lower rate than Gen Zers and millennials (76 percent). Despite fewer middle- and high-income consumers trading down compared with low-income consumers, more middle- and high-income consumers report using BNPL services (18 versus 15 percent). This may be because some BNPL services require purchases to exceed a specific amount, which may be higher than lower-income consumers are willing to spend. Together, these shifts could signal a meaningful shift in consumer spending.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSurvey responses indicate that consumers were primarily concerned about rising prices, which have grown at a higher rate than the Federal Reserve\u0026rsquo;s target inflation figure. Among the segments we track, the two with the largest real year-over-year spending increases were out-of-home entertainment and cosmetic stores, which showed a 12 percent and 13 percent increase, respectively, in real spending compared with the year prior. Among all age and income groups, the intent to splurge was most prevalent among high-income millennials. \u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/15180919"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"AE0623886A27419E818E2E07B1418657","name":"Flourish 5","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by category"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFood and travel topped the list.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Food and travel continued to be splurge-worthy categories among US consumers. True, there\u0026rsquo;s been an uptick in optimism: one-third of consumers, compared with only one-fourth in June 2022, believe the economy will rebound in just two to three months. Still, more than one in five consumers are expecting darker days ahead: 22 percent are predicting a US recession and long-term economic pain. And nearly half of survey respondents report having a \u0026ldquo;mixed\u0026rdquo; outlook: they expect the economy to recover but not for another six to 12 months. These numbers are less favorable than they were throughout 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the course of the pandemic, younger consumers have been the most optimistic about their economic future\u0026mdash;and that remains true, according to our most recent survey results. Consumers across all demographic and income segments are still spending more, but they\u0026rsquo;re being slightly more cautious than they were earlier this year. And they\u0026rsquo;re not getting more for their money: much of the spending growth has been because of inflation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRising prices have compelled most consumers to look for savings. Four out of five consumers say they\u0026rsquo;re now trading down\u0026mdash;whether by switching to a different pack size than what they normally buy (for example, a larger pack for a better price per unit or a smaller pack to stay within their weekly budget) or shopping at different stores to get the best deal.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13404873"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"5D94BFB3045B4326876EA0B546CC41A9","name":"Flourish 3","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Real spending, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpending trends have converged.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e At the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, different demographic groups varied in their spending behavior. Since then, real spending growth has ground to a halt across all groups, with both high- and low-income groups holding their spending largely flat relative to last year (on a real basis, not accounting for inflation). The same is true across age groups as well. Will spending bounce back in the summer months?\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13342592"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"7CD2AEE6472D418AA503E7F11CF5A871","name":"Flourish 4","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eYounger consumers have the urge to splurge.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Even as they look for ways to stretch their dollars, many consumers still plan to treat themselves: about 40 percent say they intend to splurge in 2023. That percentage has stayed more or less the same since late 2021. Survey respondents say they\u0026rsquo;ll spend big on food, both in restaurants and at grocery stores; fashion, especially apparel and footwear; and travel. Real spending data from May shows that consumers did not splurge on restaurants but did on travel, with a change of \u0026ndash;0.3percent and 8.1 percent, respectively.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14434364"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"23878E967FCB4644A1C073B9AEAD04C8","mediaID":{"value":"2"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"94044FA3408D49A5B4A8A574614A4E04","name":"Flourish 1","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer confidence"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eChallenges remain, but optimism is on the rise.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Well into the spring season, US consumer sentiment continues to be mixed. The percentage of consumers who are pessimistic\u0026mdash;that is, they expect a recession and a long road to economic recovery\u0026mdash;has held fairly constant in the first months of 2023, at a level higher than at any point during the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStill, there was a small uptick in optimism: 36 percent of US consumers (up from 33 percent in March 2023 and 26 percent in June 2022) expect a quick economic rebound. Optimism isn\u0026rsquo;t yet back to 2021 levels, but it\u0026rsquo;s trending in a favorable direction. Consumers in the younger demographic groups and the higher income brackets continue to be the most optimistic about their economic future\u0026mdash;a pattern that has held true throughout the pandemic and in the period after.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13784737"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"58113D340EA644E28D7CD453356639DA","name":"Flourish 2","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer spending: Real versus nominal"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eReal spending declined for the first time in more than two years.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e In March 2023, real spending fell 0.7 percent versus a year ago. The country has thus far avoided a recession, but consumers are being more financially cautious, especially in an inflationary environment where they\u0026rsquo;re not getting as much bang for their buck.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrice increases have compelled most consumers to look for ways to stretch their dollars. Trading down, as a way to manage financial pressures, is pervasive across all consumer segments\u0026mdash;but especially among Gen Z and millennials (89 percent of consumers in each of those two groups are trading down, compared with 78 percent of Gen X and 68 percent of baby boomers), low-income consumers, Black consumers (89 percent versus 78 percent of White consumers), and Hispanic consumers (86 percent). Interestingly, 89 percent of high-income millennials are trading down\u0026mdash;a much bigger percentage than the 58 percent of high-income baby boomers who are doing the same.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13784809"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"77063B02A26449EB8113FBBE270A292C","name":"Flourish 3","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Real spending, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eMost consumers\u0026mdash;even historically big spenders\u0026mdash;are pulling back.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Real spending growth has been slowing since early 2022, with both high- and low-income groups holding their spending largely flat relative to the previous year (on a real basis, not accounting for inflation). Notably, for the first time in more than two years, high-income consumers\u0026rsquo; spending growth was negative. In fact, they\u0026rsquo;ve reduced their spending more aggressively than lower-income groups have.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso, year-over-year spending by millennials is down 2 percent. Among all age groups, millennials had the highest spending growth at the peak of the pandemic. This is the first time that millennials\u0026rsquo; year-over-year spending has declined since we started tracking the data, in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13786440"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"35C2986F094B46E0AC545C54D63AB611","name":"Flourish 4","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe urge to splurge is weakening slightly.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e While Gen Zers and millennials still show much higher intent to splurge than older generations, the most recent numbers are down compared with the prior month. In March, 64 percent of Gen Z planned to splurge; leading into May, that number has fallen to 58 percent. Baby boomers have the most conservative splurging plans: even among high-income baby boomers, only 29 percent say they plan to splurge, compared with 70 percent of high-income millennials.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13786232"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"1919E97C1DA542A9BCFD76A5F2A315F3","name":"Flourish 5","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by category"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumers are still engaging in \u0026lsquo;selective indulgence.\u0026rsquo;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Even as consumers scrimp some of the time, they\u0026rsquo;re planning to spend big on certain categories. More than a third of survey respondents say they\u0026rsquo;ll splurge on food (both in restaurants and at grocery stores), travel, and apparel. Fewer than one in four intend to splurge on more \u0026ldquo;durable\u0026rdquo; purchases, such as jewelry and household goods.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13786506"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"D633CF105525449BA004CB260EFC187E","mediaID":{"value":"3"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"AC060FFAE7F24588A21629FAB1C07C95","name":"Flourish 1","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer confidence"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOptimism is trending upward\u0026mdash;but spending was flat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e As noted in last month\u0026rsquo;s update, optimism ticked up among US consumers as the spring season began. (ConsumerWise data on consumer confidence are updated on a quarterly basis.) Yet despite this modest increase in optimism, consumers\u0026rsquo; overall real year-over-year spending remained relatively flat, as the next chart shows.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14199482"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"0A16F100F79F4A94A1803B87B948D879","name":"Flourish 2","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer spending: Real versus nominal"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOverall real spending was flat versus a year ago.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e In April 2023, consumer spending (as measured by credit card spending) was essentially flat, up 0.1 percent from last year, with the nominal growth rate coming in at around 3.5 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong retailer segments, jewelry retailers saw the largest negative change (\u0026ndash;9.1 percent) in real year-over-year spending. Meanwhile, the fitness retailer segment continued to show resilience, with real year-over-year growth of 6.4 percent. Heading into the summer, the travel retailer segment is seeing real year-over-year growth of 5.2 percent, with the steamship and cruise line subsegments experiencing the largest real year-over-year spending increase among all retailer subsegments.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14145228"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"E128669BA58045ADA6809414E1794BD0","name":"Flourish 3","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Real spending, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpending was down in some demographic groups. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eThe decline in overall real spending growth generally flattened out in April 2023. Spending was down among some groups, including low-income consumers and millennials (\u0026ndash;0.9 and \u0026ndash;0.1 percent, respectively), while the remaining demographic groups showed either flat or slightly elevated change from a year ago.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14145527"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"563502C7D6B14512AF18CDC7B037BB20","name":"Flourish 4","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by demographic"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntent hasn\u0026rsquo;t translated into action.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Consumers don\u0026rsquo;t always do what they intend to do. As this chart shows, in April 2023 at least half of Gen Zers and millennials in every income group said they were planning to splurge. However, the rate of change in real year-over-year spending in April was nearly flat (0.1 to 0.3 percent) or negative (\u0026ndash;0.9 percent) across all Gen Z and millennial income groups.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14199487"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"7FE1A0B2BE86420AA44494A05B57197F","name":"Flourish 5","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge, by category"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSome categories seem to be benefiting from the intent to splurge.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e The results of our consumer sentiment survey, conducted early in the second quarter of 2023, showed that consumers planned to splurge on several categories. Did they actually do so? Perhaps just a little. For instance, 41 percent of respondents expressed intent to splurge on restaurants, but the year-over-year change in real spending in the restaurant retail segment showed only slight growth of 0.3
